sn3.22:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn3.22:1.2.eng: King Pasenadi of Kosala sat to one side, and the Buddha said to him,

sn3.22:1.3.pli: “handa kuto nu tvaṃ, mahārāja, āgacchasi divādivassā”ti?
sn3.22:1.3.eng: “So, great king, where are you coming from in the middle of the day?”

sn3.22:2.1.pli: “Ayyikā me, bhante, kālaṅkatā jiṇṇā vuḍḍhā mahallikā addhagatā vayoanuppattā vīsavassasatikā jātiyā.
sn3.22:2.1.eng: “Sir, my grandmother has passed away. She was old, elderly and senior. She was advanced in years and had reached the final stage of life; she was a hundred and twenty years old.

sn3.22:2.2.pli: Ayyikā kho pana me, bhante, piyā hoti manāpā.
sn3.22:2.2.eng: But I loved my grandmother; she was dear to me.

sn3.22:2.3.pli: Hatthiratanena cepāhaṃ, bhante, labheyyaṃ ‘mā me ayyikā kālamakāsī’ti, hatthiratanampāhaṃ dadeyyaṃ:
sn3.22:2.3.eng: If by giving away the elephant-treasure I could get my grandmother back, I’d do it.

sn3.22:2.5.pli: Assaratanena cepāhaṃ, bhante, labheyyaṃ ‘mā me ayyikā kālamakāsī’ti, assaratanampāhaṃ dadeyyaṃ:
sn3.22:2.5.eng: If by giving away the horse-treasure I could get my grandmother back, I’d do it.

sn3.22:2.7.pli: Gāmavarena cepāhaṃ, bhante, labheyyaṃ ‘mā me ayyikā kālamakāsī’ti, gāmavarampāhaṃ dadeyyaṃ:
sn3.22:2.7.eng: If by giving away a prize village I could get my grandmother back, I’d do it.

sn3.22:2.9.pli: Janapadapadesena cepāhaṃ, bhante, labheyyaṃ ‘mā me ayyikā kālamakāsī’ti, janapadapadesampāhaṃ dadeyyaṃ:
sn3.22:2.9.eng: If by giving away the whole country I could get my grandmother back, I’d do it.”

sn3.22:2.11.pli: “Sabbe sattā, mahārāja, maraṇadhammā maraṇapariyosānā maraṇaṃ anatītā”ti.
sn3.22:2.11.eng: “Great king, all sentient beings are liable to die. Death is their end; they’re not exempt from death.”

sn3.22:2.13.eng: how well said this was by the Buddha:

sn3.22:2.14.pli: sabbe sattā maraṇadhammā maraṇapariyosānā maraṇaṃ anatītā’”ti.
sn3.22:2.14.eng: ‘All sentient beings are liable to die. Death is their end; they’re not exempt from death.’”

sn3.22:3.1.eng: “That’s so true, great king! That’s so true!

sn3.22:3.2.pli: Sabbe sattā maraṇadhammā maraṇapariyosānā maraṇaṃ anatītā.
sn3.22:3.2.eng: All sentient beings are liable to die. Death is their end; they’re not exempt from death.

sn3.22:3.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, yāni kānici kumbhakārabhājanāni āmakāni ceva pakkāni ca sabbāni tāni bhedanadhammāni bhedanapariyosānāni bhedanaṃ anatītāni;
sn3.22:3.3.eng: It’s like the vessels made by potters. Whatever kind they are, whether baked or unbaked, all of them are liable to break apart. Breaking is their end; they’re not exempt from breakage.

sn3.22:3.4.pli: evameva kho, mahārāja, sabbe sattā maraṇadhammā maraṇapariyosānā maraṇaṃ anatītā”ti.
sn3.22:3.4.eng: In the same way, all sentient beings are liable to die. Death is their end; they’re not exempt from death.”

sn3.22:3.5.eng: That is what the Buddha said. …

sn3.22:4.3.eng: They pass on according to their deeds,

sn3.22:4.4.eng: reaping the fruits of good and bad.

sn3.22:4.5.eng: Those who do bad go to hell,

sn3.22:4.6.eng: and if you do good you go to heaven.

sn3.22:5.1.eng: That’s why you should do good,

sn3.22:5.3.eng: The good deeds of sentient beings

sn3.22:5.4.eng: support them in the next world.”

sn3.23:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn3.23:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, King Pasenadi said to the Buddha,

sn3.23:1.3.pli: “kati nu kho, bhante, lokassa dhammā uppajjamānā uppajjanti ahitāya dukkhāya aphāsuvihārāyā”ti?
sn3.23:1.3.eng: “Sir, how many things arise in the world for its harm, suffering, and discomfort?”

sn3.23:1.4.pli: “Tayo kho, mahārāja, lokassa dhammā uppajjamānā uppajjanti ahitāya dukkhāya aphāsuvihārāya.
sn3.23:1.4.eng: “Great king, three things arise in the world for its harm, suffering, and discomfort.

sn3.23:1.6.pli: Lobho kho, mahārāja, lokassa dhammo, uppajjamāno uppajjati ahitāya dukkhāya aphāsuvihārāya.

sn3.23:1.7.pli: Doso kho, mahārāja, lokassa dhammo, uppajjamāno uppajjati ahitāya dukkhāya aphāsuvihārāya.

sn3.23:1.8.pli: Moho kho, mahārāja, lokassa dhammo, uppajjamāno uppajjati ahitāya dukkhāya aphāsuvihārāya.

sn3.23:1.9.pli: Ime kho, mahārāja, tayo lokassa dhammā uppajjamānā uppajjanti ahitāya dukkhāya aphāsuvihārāyā”ti.
sn3.23:1.9.eng: These three things arise in the world for its harm, suffering, and discomfort.”

sn3.23:1.10.eng: That is what the Buddha said. …

sn3.23:2.3.eng: they harm a person of wicked heart,

sn3.23:2.4.eng: as a bamboo is destroyed by its own fruit.”

sn3.24:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn3.24:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, King Pasenadi said to the Buddha,

sn3.24:1.3.eng: “Sir, where should a gift be given?”

sn3.24:1.4.eng: “Wherever your heart feels inspired, great king.”

sn3.24:1.5.eng: “But sir, where is a gift very fruitful?”
sn3.24:1.5.comm: Also asked by the brahmin Devahita at SN 7.13:7.2 and by Sakka at SN 11.16:2.4.

sn3.24:1.6.pli: “Aññaṃ kho etaṃ, mahārāja, kattha dānaṃ dātabbaṃ, aññaṃ panetaṃ kattha dinnaṃ mahapphalanti?
sn3.24:1.6.eng: “Where a gift should be given is one thing, great king, but where a gift is very fruitful is another.
sn3.24:1.6.comm: Giving is not purely a matter of utilitarian calculation. It creates an emotional connection, which is why giving with one’s own hands is important. It’s not just about helping another; it’s also about elevating oneself.

sn3.24:1.7.pli: Sīlavato kho, mahārāja, dinnaṃ mahapphalaṃ, no tathā dussīle.
sn3.24:1.7.eng: A gift is very fruitful when it’s given to an ethical person, not so much to an unethical person.

sn3.24:1.8.pli: Tena hi, mahārāja, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi. Yathā, te khameyya, tathā naṃ byākareyyāsi.
sn3.24:1.8.eng: Well then, great king, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.

sn3.24:1.9.eng: What do you think, great king?

sn3.24:1.10.pli: idha tyassa yuddhaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ saṅgāmo samupabyūḷho.
sn3.24:1.10.eng: Suppose you were at war, ready to fight a battle.

sn3.24:1.11.pli: Atha āgaccheyya khattiyakumāro asikkhito akatahattho akatayoggo akatūpāsano bhīru chambhī utrāsī palāyī.
sn3.24:1.11.eng: Then along comes an aristocrat youth who is untrained, inexpert, unfit, inexperienced. And he’s fearful, scared, nervous, quick to flee.

sn3.24:1.12.pli: Bhareyyāsi taṃ purisaṃ, attho ca te tādisena purisenā”ti?
sn3.24:1.12.eng: Would you employ such a man? Would he be of any use to you?”

sn3.24:1.13.pli: “Nāhaṃ, bhante, bhareyyaṃ taṃ purisaṃ, na ca me attho tādisena purisenā”ti.
sn3.24:1.13.eng: “No, sir, I would have no use for such a man.”

sn3.24:1.14.comm: Note that, while the khattiyas were often said to be the warrior class, there is no difference here.

sn3.24:1.16.eng: or a menial youth who was similar?”

sn3.24:1.17.pli: na ca me attho tādisena purisenā”ti.
sn3.24:1.17.eng: “No, sir, I would have no use for such a man.”

sn3.24:2.2.pli: idha tyassa yuddhaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ saṅgāmo samupabyūḷho.
sn3.24:2.2.eng: Suppose you were at war, ready to fight a battle.

sn3.24:2.3.pli: Atha āgaccheyya khattiyakumāro susikkhito katahattho katayoggo katūpāsano abhīru acchambhī anutrāsī apalāyī.
sn3.24:2.3.eng: Then along comes an aristocrat youth who is trained, expert, fit, experienced. And he’s fearless, brave, bold, standing his ground.

sn3.24:2.4.pli: Bhareyyāsi taṃ purisaṃ, attho ca te tādisena purisenā”ti?
sn3.24:2.4.eng: Would you employ such a man? Would he be of any use to you?”

sn3.24:2.5.pli: “Bhareyyāhaṃ, bhante, taṃ purisaṃ, attho ca me tādisena purisenā”ti.
sn3.24:2.5.eng: “Yes, sir, I would have a use for such a man.”

sn3.24:2.8.pli: atha āgaccheyya suddakumāro susikkhito katahattho katayoggo katūpāsano abhīru acchambhī anutrāsī apalāyī.
sn3.24:2.8.eng: or a menial youth who was similar?

sn3.24:2.9.pli: Bhareyyāsi taṃ purisaṃ, attho ca te tādisena purisenā”ti?
sn3.24:2.9.eng: Would you employ such a man? Would he be of any use to you?”

sn3.24:2.10.pli: “Bhareyyāhaṃ, bhante, taṃ purisaṃ, attho ca me tādisena purisenā”ti.
sn3.24:2.10.eng: “Yes, sir, I would have a use for such a man.”

sn3.24:3.1.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, yasmā kasmā cepi kulā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito hoti, so ca hoti pañcaṅgavippahīno pañcaṅgasamannāgato, tasmiṃ dinnaṃ mahapphalaṃ hoti.
sn3.24:3.1.eng: “In the same way, a gift to anyone who has given up five factors and possesses five factors is very fruitful, no matter what family they’ve gone forth from.

sn3.24:3.2.eng: What are the five factors they’ve given up?

sn3.24:3.3.pli: Kāmacchando pahīno hoti, byāpādo pahīno hoti, thinamiddhaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti, uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti, vicikicchā pahīnā hoti.
sn3.24:3.3.eng: Sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.

sn3.24:3.4.eng: These are the five factors they’ve given up.

sn3.24:3.5.eng: What are the five factors they possess?

sn3.24:3.6.pli: Asekkhena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato hoti, asekkhena samādhikkhandhena samannāgato hoti, asekkhena paññākkhandhena samannāgato hoti, asekkhena vimuttikkhandhena samannāgato hoti, asekkhena vimuttiñāṇadassanakkhandhena samannāgato hoti.
sn3.24:3.6.eng: The entire spectrum of an adept’s ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and knowledge and vision of freedom.

sn3.24:3.7.eng: These are the five factors they possess.

sn3.24:3.8.eng: I say that a gift to anyone who has given up these five factors and possesses these five factors is very fruitful.”

sn3.24:3.9.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn3.24:3.10.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

sn3.24:4.3.eng: would be employed by a king going to war—

sn3.24:4.4.eng: one is not a coward by reason of birth.

sn3.24:5.2.eng: in the qualities of patience and gentleness,

sn3.24:5.3.eng: a clever person with noble conduct,

sn3.24:5.4.eng: should be venerated even if they’re low born.

sn3.24:6.2.eng: and settle learned people in them.

sn3.24:6.3.eng: You should set up water supplies in barren regions

sn3.24:6.4.eng: and passages in places hard to travel.

sn3.24:7.3.eng: should be given to the upright ones,

sn3.24:7.4.eng: with a clear and confident heart.

sn3.24:8.2.eng: its hundred peaks wreathed in lightning,

sn3.24:8.3.eng: pours down over the rich earth,

sn3.24:9.3.eng: should prepare a meal to satisfy

sn3.24:10.4.eng: like rain sent from the heavens.

sn3.24:10.5.eng: That stream of merit so abundant

sn3.25:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn3.25:1.2.eng: King Pasenadi of Kosala sat to one side, and the Buddha said to him,

sn3.25:1.3.pli: “handa kuto nu tvaṃ, mahārāja, āgacchasi divā divassā”ti?
sn3.25:1.3.eng: “So, great king, where are you coming from in the middle of the day?”

sn3.25:1.4.pli: “Yāni tāni, bhante, raññaṃ khattiyānaṃ muddhāvasittānaṃ issariyamadamattānaṃ kāmagedhapariyuṭṭhitānaṃ janapadatthāvariyappattānaṃ mahantaṃ pathavimaṇḍalaṃ abhivijiya ajjhāvasantānaṃ rājakaraṇīyāni bhavanti, tesu khvāhaṃ, etarahi ussukkamāpanno”ti.
sn3.25:1.4.eng: “Sir, there are anointed aristocratic kings who are infatuated with authority, and obsessed with greed for sensual pleasures. They have attained stability in the country, occupying a vast conquered territory. Today I have been busy fulfilling the duties of such kings.”

sn3.25:2.2.pli: idha te puriso āgaccheyya puratthimāya disāya saddhāyiko paccayiko.
sn3.25:2.2.eng: Suppose a trustworthy and dependable man were to come from the east.

sn3.25:2.4.pli: ‘yagghe, mahārāja, jāneyyāsi, ahaṃ āgacchāmi puratthimāya disāya.
sn3.25:2.4.eng: ‘Please great king, you should know this. I come from the east.

sn3.25:2.5.pli: Tatthaddasaṃ mahantaṃ pabbataṃ abbhasamaṃ, sabbe pāṇe nippothento āgacchati.
sn3.25:2.5.eng: There I saw a huge mountain that reached the clouds. And it was coming this way, crushing all creatures.
sn3.25:2.5.comm: This extraordinary threat looms also in an Upaniṣadic passage: “Even if both the mountain ranges, the southern and the northern, were to rush at him determined to level him, they would not succeed in leveling him” (Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad 2.13, translation Olivelle).

sn3.25:2.6.pli: Yaṃ te, mahārāja, karaṇīyaṃ, taṃ karohī’ti.
sn3.25:2.6.eng: So then, great king, do what you must!’

sn3.25:2.7.pli: Atha dutiyo puriso āgaccheyya pacchimāya disāya …pe…
sn3.25:2.7.eng: Then a second trustworthy and dependable man were to come from the west …

sn3.25:2.8.pli: atha tatiyo puriso āgaccheyya uttarāya disāya …

sn3.25:2.9.pli: atha catuttho puriso āgaccheyya dakkhiṇāya disāya saddhāyiko paccayiko.
sn3.25:2.9.eng: and a fourth from the south.

sn3.25:2.11.pli: ‘yagghe, mahārāja, jāneyyāsi, ahaṃ āgacchāmi dakkhiṇāya disāya.
sn3.25:2.11.eng: ‘Please great king, you should know this. I come from the south.

sn3.25:2.12.pli: Tatthaddasaṃ mahantaṃ pabbataṃ abbhasamaṃ sabbe pāṇe nippothento āgacchati.
sn3.25:2.12.eng: There I saw a huge mountain that reached the clouds. And it was coming this way, crushing all creatures.

sn3.25:2.13.pli: Yaṃ te, mahārāja, karaṇīyaṃ taṃ karohī’ti.
sn3.25:2.13.eng: So then, great king, do what you must!’

sn3.25:2.14.pli: Evarūpe te, mahārāja, mahati mahabbhaye samuppanne dāruṇe manussakkhaye dullabhe manussatte kimassa karaṇīyan”ti?
sn3.25:2.14.eng: Should such a dire threat arise—a grim loss of human life, when human birth is so rare—what would you do?”

sn3.25:3.1.pli: “Evarūpe me, bhante, mahati mahabbhaye samuppanne dāruṇe manussakkhaye dullabhe manussatte kimassa karaṇīyaṃ aññatra dhammacariyāya aññatra samacariyāya aññatra kusalakiriyāya aññatra puññakiriyāyā”ti?
sn3.25:3.1.eng: “Sir, what could I do but practice the teachings, practice morality, doing skillful and good actions?”

sn3.25:4.1.pli: “Ārocemi kho te, mahārāja, paṭivedemi kho te, mahārāja, adhivattati kho taṃ, mahārāja, jarāmaraṇaṃ.
sn3.25:4.1.eng: “I tell you, great king, I announce to you: old age and death are advancing upon you.

sn3.25:4.2.pli: Adhivattamāne ce te, mahārāja, jarāmaraṇe kimassa karaṇīyan”ti?
sn3.25:4.2.eng: Since old age and death are advancing upon you, what would you do?”

sn3.25:4.3.pli: “Adhivattamāne ca me, bhante, jarāmaraṇe kimassa karaṇīyaṃ aññatra dhammacariyāya samacariyāya kusalakiriyāya puññakiriyāya?
sn3.25:4.3.eng: “Sir, what can I do but practice the teachings, practice morality, doing skillful and good actions?

sn3.25:4.4.pli: Yāni tāni, bhante, raññaṃ khattiyānaṃ muddhāvasittānaṃ issariyamadamattānaṃ kāmagedhapariyuṭṭhitānaṃ janapadatthāvariyappattānaṃ mahantaṃ pathavimaṇḍalaṃ abhivijiya ajjhāvasantānaṃ hatthiyuddhāni bhavanti;
sn3.25:4.4.eng: Sir, there are anointed aristocratic kings who are infatuated with authority, and obsessed with greed for sensual pleasures. They have attained stability in the country, occupying a vast conquered territory. Such kings engage in battles of elephants,

sn3.25:4.5.pli: tesampi, bhante, hatthiyuddhānaṃ natthi gati natthi visayo adhivattamāne jarāmaraṇe.

sn3.25:4.6.pli: Yānipi tāni, bhante, raññaṃ khattiyānaṃ muddhāvasittānaṃ …pe…

sn3.25:4.10.pli: tesampi, bhante, pattiyuddhānaṃ natthi gati natthi visayo adhivattamāne jarāmaraṇe.
sn3.25:4.10.eng: But there is no place, no domain for such battles when old age and death are advancing.

sn3.25:4.11.pli: Santi kho pana, bhante, imasmiṃ rājakule mantino mahāmattā, ye pahonti āgate paccatthike mantehi bhedayituṃ.
sn3.25:4.11.eng: In this royal court there are ministers of wise counsel who are capable of dividing an approaching enemy by wise counsel.

sn3.25:4.12.pli: Tesampi, bhante, mantayuddhānaṃ natthi gati natthi visayo adhivattamāne jarāmaraṇe.
sn3.25:4.12.eng: But there is no place, no domain for such diplomatic battles when old age and death are advancing.

sn3.25:4.13.pli: Saṃvijjati kho pana, bhante, imasmiṃ rājakule pahūtaṃ hiraññasuvaṇṇaṃ bhūmigatañceva vehāsaṭṭhañca, yena mayaṃ pahoma āgate paccatthike dhanena upalāpetuṃ.
sn3.25:4.13.eng: In this royal court there is abundant gold, both coined and uncoined, stored above and below ground. Using this wealth we can bribe an approaching enemy.
sn3.25:4.13.comm: Bhūmigata is explained as “underground” at Bu Pj 2:4.2.1 (there bhūmaṭṭha). | Vehāsaṭṭha is explained as “above ground” at Bu Pj 2:4.5.1. | Upalāpetuṁ (“bribe”) is a means by which Vassakāra suggests the Vajjis can be overcome (DN 16:1.5.8, AN 7.22:12.3).

sn3.25:4.14.pli: Tesampi, bhante, dhanayuddhānaṃ natthi gati natthi visayo adhivattamāne jarāmaraṇe.
sn3.25:4.14.eng: But there is no place, no domain for such monetary battles when old age and death are advancing.

sn3.25:4.15.pli: Adhivattamāne ca me, bhante, jarāmaraṇe kimassa karaṇīyaṃ aññatra dhammacariyāya samacariyāya kusalakiriyāya puññakiriyāyā”ti?
sn3.25:4.15.eng: When old age and death are advancing, what can I do but practice the teachings, practice morality, doing skillful and good actions?”

sn3.25:5.1.eng: “That’s so true, great king! That’s so true!

sn3.25:5.2.pli: Adhivattamāne jarāmaraṇe kimassa karaṇīyaṃ aññatra dhammacariyāya samacariyāya kusalakiriyāya puññakiriyāyā”ti?
sn3.25:5.2.eng: When old age and death are advancing, what can you do but practice the teachings, practice morality, doing skillful and good actions?”

sn3.25:5.3.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn3.25:5.4.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

sn3.25:6.2.eng: of solid rock pressing against the sky

sn3.25:7.1.eng: So too old age and death

sn3.25:8.1.eng: There’s nowhere for elephants to take a stand,

sn3.25:8.4.eng: by diplomatic battles or by wealth.

sn3.25:9.4.eng: in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha.

sn3.25:10.4.eng: and departs to rejoice in heaven.”

sn3.25:11.5.eng: The Linked Discourses with the Kosalan are completed.

sn3.3:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn3.3:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, King Pasenadi said to the Buddha,

sn3.3:1.3.pli: “atthi nu kho, bhante, jātassa aññatra jarāmaraṇā”ti?
sn3.3:1.3.eng: “Sir, for someone who has been reborn, is there any exemption from old age and death?”
sn3.3:1.3.comm: The subtext is that once one has obtained kingship, immortality becomes tempting.

sn3.3:1.4.eng: “Great king, for someone who has been reborn, there’s no exemption from old age and death.

sn3.3:1.5.pli: Yepi te, mahārāja, khattiyamahāsālā aḍḍhā mahaddhanā mahābhogā pahūtajātarūparajatā pahūtavittūpakaraṇā pahūtadhanadhaññā, tesampi jātānaṃ natthi aññatra jarāmaraṇā.

sn3.3:1.7.pli: gahapatimahāsālā aḍḍhā mahaddhanā mahābhogā pahūtajātarūparajatā pahūtavittūpakaraṇā pahūtadhanadhaññā, tesampi jātānaṃ natthi aññatra jarāmaraṇā.
sn3.3:1.7.eng: or householders—rich, affluent, and wealthy, with lots of gold and silver, lots of property and assets, and lots of money and grain—when they’re born, there’s no exemption from old age and death.

sn3.3:1.8.pli: Yepi te, mahārāja, bhikkhū arahanto khīṇāsavā vusitavanto katakaraṇīyā ohitabhārā anuppattasadatthā parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojanā sammadaññāvimuttā, tesampāyaṃ kāyo bhedanadhammo nikkhepanadhammo”ti.
sn3.3:1.8.eng: Even for mendicants who are perfected—who have ended the defilements, completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and are rightly freed through enlightenment—their bodies are liable to break up and be laid to rest.”

sn3.3:1.9.eng: That is what the Buddha said. …

sn3.3:2.2.eng: and even this body gets old.

sn3.3:2.3.eng: But the truth of the good never gets old—
sn3.3:2.3.comm: These two lines contain three forms of the same word santa, “a good person”: sataṁ is genitive plural; santo is nominative plural; sabbhi is dative plural (following Brough and Norman).

sn3.3:2.4.eng: so the good proclaim to the good.”

sn3.4:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn3.4:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, King Pasenadi said to the Buddha,

sn3.4:1.3.pli: “idha mayhaṃ, bhante, rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
sn3.4:1.3.eng: “Just now, sir, as I was in private retreat this thought came to mind.
sn3.4:1.3.comm: Here again we see a progress in their relationship. Now Paseandi is reflecting on the Dhamma and bringing his own thoughts to the Buddha. Even though Pasenadi is not said to have attained any of the noble paths, this Sutta reveals an insightful grasp of human psychology.

sn3.4:1.4.pli: ‘kesaṃ nu kho piyo attā, kesaṃ appiyo attā’ti?
sn3.4:1.4.eng: ‘Who are those who love themselves? And who are those who don’t love themselves?’

sn3.4:1.6.pli: ‘ye ca kho keci kāyena duccaritaṃ caranti, vācāya duccaritaṃ caranti, manasā duccaritaṃ caranti;
sn3.4:1.6.eng: ‘Those who do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind

sn3.4:1.9.pli: “piyo no attā”ti, atha kho tesaṃ appiyo attā’.

sn3.4:1.11.pli: Yañhi appiyo appiyassa kareyya, taṃ te attanāva attano karonti;
sn3.4:1.11.eng: It’s because they treat themselves like an enemy.

sn3.4:1.12.eng: That’s why they don’t love themselves.

sn3.4:1.13.pli: Ye ca kho keci kāyena sucaritaṃ caranti, vācāya sucaritaṃ caranti, manasā sucaritaṃ caranti;
sn3.4:1.13.eng: Those who do good things by way of body, speech, and mind

sn3.4:1.16.pli: ‘appiyo no attā’ti; atha kho tesaṃ piyo attā.
sn3.4:1.16.eng: “I don’t love myself”, they do really.

sn3.4:1.18.pli: Yañhi piyo piyassa kareyya, taṃ te attanāva attano karonti;
sn3.4:1.18.eng: It’s because they treat themselves like a loved one.

sn3.4:1.19.eng: That’s why they do love themselves.’”
sn3.4:1.19.comm: Action is paramount because it is the cause of feelings and emotions. The path forward starts with recognizing that it is within your power to change how you treat yourself.

sn3.4:2.1.eng: “That’s so true, great king! That’s so true!” said the Buddha. And he repeated the king’s statement, adding:

sn3.4:2.2.pli: Ye hi keci, mahārāja, kāyena duccaritaṃ caranti, vācāya duccaritaṃ caranti, manasā duccaritaṃ caranti;

sn3.4:2.5.pli: ‘piyo no attā’ti, atha kho tesaṃ appiyo attā.

sn3.4:2.7.pli: Yañhi, mahārāja, appiyo appiyassa kareyya, taṃ te attanāva attano karonti;

sn3.4:2.9.pli: Ye ca kho keci, mahārāja, kāyena sucaritaṃ caranti, vācāya sucaritaṃ caranti, manasā sucaritaṃ caranti;

sn3.4:2.15.pli: Yañhi, mahārāja, piyo piyassa kareyya, taṃ te attanāva attano karonti;

sn3.4:3.1.eng: “If you knew your self as beloved,

sn3.4:3.2.eng: you’d not yoke yourself to wickedness.

sn3.4:3.3.eng: For happiness is not easy to find

sn3.4:3.4.eng: by someone who does bad deeds.

sn3.4:4.1.eng: When you’re seized by the terminator
sn3.4:4.1.comm: The “terminator” (antaka) is death, sometimes personified as Māra (eg. SN 4.1:6.4).

sn3.4:4.2.eng: as you give up your human life,

sn3.4:4.3.eng: what can you call your own?

sn3.4:4.4.eng: What do you take when you go?

sn3.4:4.6.eng: like a shadow that never leaves?
sn3.4:4.6.comm: This simile also employed at Dhp 2, Thag 17.3:28, and MN 91:8.4.

sn3.4:5.1.eng: Both the good and the bad

sn3.4:5.2.eng: that a mortal does in this life

sn3.4:5.3.eng: is what they can call their own.
sn3.4:5.3.comm: That deeds (kamma) are one’s own (saka) is a stock reflection (eg. MN 135:4.1, AN 5.57:1.7).

sn3.4:5.4.eng: That’s what they take when they go.

sn3.4:5.6.eng: like a shadow that never leaves.

sn3.4:6.1.eng: That’s why you should do good,

sn3.4:6.2.comm: Nicaya (“investing”) is more literally, “piling up”.

sn3.4:6.3.eng: The good deeds of sentient beings

sn3.4:6.4.eng: support them in the next world.”
